result.markdown:
--- title: Visualizing time series data II subtitle: Lecture 9 title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: ../vizdata-bg.png data-background-size: 800px, cover data-slide-number: none format: revealjs highlight-style: a11y execute: code-link: true warning: true editor_options: chunk_output_type: console --- ## Setup {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # load packages library(countdown) library(tidyverse) library(lubridate) library(janitor) library(colorspace) library(broom) library(fs) # set theme for ggplot2 ggplot2::theme_set(ggplot2::theme_minimal(base_size = 14)) # set width of code output options(width = 65) # set figure parameters for knitr knitr::opts_chunk$set( fig.width = 7, # 7" width fig.asp = 0.618, # the golden ratio fig.retina = 3, # dpi multiplier for displaying HTML output on retina fig.align = "center", # center align figures dpi = 300 # higher dpi, sharper image ) ``` ::: # Working with dates ## AQI levels The previous graphic in tibble form, to be used later... ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} aqi_levels <- tribble( ~aqi_min, ~aqi_max, ~color, ~level, 0, 50, "#D8EEDA", "Good", 51, 100, "#F1E7D4", "Moderate", 101, 150, "#F8E4D8", "Unhealthy for sensitive groups", 151, 200, "#FEE2E1", "Unhealthy", 201, 300, "#F4E3F7", "Very unhealthy", 301, 400, "#F9D0D4", "Hazardous" ) ``` ::: ## AQI data - Source: [EPA's Daily Air Quality Tracker](https://www.epa.gov/outdoor-air-quality-data/air-data-daily-air-quality-tracker) - 2016 - 2022 AQI (Ozone and PM2.5 combined) for Tucson, AZ core-based statistical area (CBSA), one file per year - 2016 - 2022 AQI (Ozone and PM2.5 combined) for San Francisco-Oakland-Hayward, CA CBSA, one file per year ## 2022 Tucson, AZ {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc_2022 <- read_csv( here::here("data/tucson/ad_aqi_tracker_data-2022.csv"), na = c(".", "") ) ``` ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc_2022 <- tuc_2022 |> janitor::clean_names() |> mutate(date = mdy(date)) tuc_2022 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 365 × 11 date aqi_value main_pollutant site_name site_id source 1 2022-01-01 40 PM2.5 GERONIMO 04-019-11… AQS 2 2022-01-02 55 PM2.5 GERONIMO 04-019-11… AQS 3 2022-01-03 55 PM2.5 GERONIMO 04-019-11… AQS # ℹ 362 more rows # ℹ 5 more variables: x20_year_high_2000_2019 , # x20_year_low_2000_2019 , # x5_year_average_2015_2019 , date_of_20_year_high , # date_of_20_year_low ``` ::: ::: ## Visualizing Tucson AQI ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-time-series-II_files/figure-revealjs/tuc-2022-2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Another visualization of Tucson AQI ::: task Recreate the following visualization. ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-time-series-II_files/figure-revealjs/tuc-2022-3-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ````{=html} ```` ## Highlights - The **lubridate** package is useful for converting to dates from character strings in a given format, e.g. `mdy()`, `ymd()`, etc. - The **colorspace** package is useful for programmatically darkening / lightening colors - `scale_x_date`: Set `date_labels` as `"%b %y"` for month-2 digit year, `"%D"` for date format such as `%m/%d/%y`, etc. See help for `strptime()` for more. - `scale_color_identity()` or `scale_fill_identity()` can be useful when your data already represents aesthetic values that ggplot2 can handle directly. By default doesn't produce a legend. # Calculating cumulatives ## Cumulatives over time - When visualizing time series data, a somewhat common task is to calculate cumulatives over time and plot them - In our example we'll calculate the number of days with "good" AQI ($\le$ 50) and plot that value on the y-axis and the date on the x-axis ## Calculating cumulatives Step 1. Arrange your data ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc_2022 |> select(date, aqi_value) |> filter(!is.na(aqi_value)) |> arrange(date) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 365 × 2 date aqi_value 1 2022-01-01 40 2 2022-01-02 55 3 2022-01-03 55 4 2022-01-04 48 5 2022-01-05 50 # ℹ 360 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Calculating cumulatives Step 2. Identify good days ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc_2022 |> select(date, aqi_value) |> filter(!is.na(aqi_value)) |> arrange(date) |> mutate(good_aqi = if_else(aqi_value <= 50, 1, 0)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 365 × 3 date aqi_value good_aqi 1 2022-01-01 40 1 2 2022-01-02 55 0 3 2022-01-03 55 0 4 2022-01-04 48 1 5 2022-01-05 50 1 # ℹ 360 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Calculating cumulatives Step 3. Sum over time ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc_2022 |> select(date, aqi_value) |> filter(!is.na(aqi_value)) |> arrange(date) |> mutate( good_aqi = if_else(aqi_value <= 50, 1, 0), cumsum_good_aqi = cumsum(good_aqi) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 365 × 4 date aqi_value good_aqi cumsum_good_aqi 1 2022-01-01 40 1 1 2 2022-01-02 55 0 1 3 2022-01-03 55 0 1 4 2022-01-04 48 1 2 5 2022-01-05 50 1 3 # ℹ 360 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Plotting cumulatives {.smaller} ::: panel-tabset ### Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-time-series-II_files/figure-revealjs/tucson-aqi-3-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ### Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc_2022 |> select(date, aqi_value) |> filter(!is.na(aqi_value)) |> arrange(date) |> mutate( good_aqi = if_else(aqi_value <= 50, 1, 0), cumsum_good_aqi = cumsum(good_aqi) ) |> ggplot(aes(x = date, y = cumsum_good_aqi, group = 1)) + geom_line() + scale_x_date(date_labels = "%b %Y") + labs( x = NULL, y = "Number of days", title = "Cumulative number of good AQI days (AQI < 50)", subtitle = "Tucson, AZ", caption = "\nSource: EPA Daily Air Quality Tracker" ) + theme(plot.title.position = "plot") ``` ::: ::: # Detrending ## Detrending - Detrending is removing prominent long-term trend in time series to specifically highlight any notable deviations - Let's demonstrate using multiple years of AQI data ## Multiple years of Tucson, AZ data {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc_files <- fs::dir_ls(here::here("data/tucson")) tuc_files ``` ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` /Users/gchism/Desktop/INFO-526-SU24/slides/09/data/tucson/ad_aqi_tracker_data-2017.csv /Users/gchism/Desktop/INFO-526-SU24/slides/09/data/tucson/ad_aqi_tracker_data-2018.csv /Users/gchism/Desktop/INFO-526-SU24/slides/09/data/tucson/ad_aqi_tracker_data-2019.csv /Users/gchism/Desktop/INFO-526-SU24/slides/09/data/tucson/ad_aqi_tracker_data-2020.csv /Users/gchism/Desktop/INFO-526-SU24/slides/09/data/tucson/ad_aqi_tracker_data-2021.csv /Users/gchism/Desktop/INFO-526-SU24/slides/09/data/tucson/ad_aqi_tracker_data-2022.csv /Users/gchism/Desktop/INFO-526-SU24/slides/09/data/tucson/ad_aqi_tracker_data-2023.csv ``` ::: ::: ## Reading multiple files {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc <- read_csv(tuc_files, na = c(".", "")) tuc <- tuc |> janitor::clean_names() |> mutate( date = mdy(date), good_aqi = if_else(aqi_value <= 50, 1, 0) ) |> filter(!is.na(aqi_value)) |> arrange(date) |> mutate(cumsum_good_aqi = cumsum(good_aqi), .after = aqi_value) tuc ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2,392 × 13 date aqi_value cumsum_good_aqi main_pollutant site_name 1 2017-01-01 38 1 Ozone SAGUARO PA… 2 2017-01-02 40 2 Ozone SAGUARO PA… 3 2017-01-03 38 3 Ozone SAGUARO PA… 4 2017-01-04 38 4 Ozone SAGUARO PA… 5 2017-01-05 32 5 Ozone SAGUARO PA… # ℹ 2,387 more rows # ℹ 8 more variables: site_id , source , # x20_year_high_2000_2019 , x20_year_low_2000_2019 , # x5_year_average_2015_2019 , date_of_20_year_high , # date_of_20_year_low , good_aqi ``` ::: ::: ## Plot trend since 2016 {.smaller} ::: panel-tabset ### Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-time-series-II_files/figure-revealjs/tuc-3-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ### Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="6|7"} tuc |> ggplot(aes(x = date, y = cumsum_good_aqi, group = 1)) + geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "pink") + geom_line() + scale_x_date( expand = expansion(mult = 0.02), date_labels = "%Y" ) + labs( x = NULL, y = "Number of days", title = "Cumulative number of good AQI days (AQI < 50)", subtitle = "Tucson, AZ", caption = "\nSource: EPA Daily Air Quality Tracker" ) + theme(plot.title.position = "plot") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Detrend Step 1. Fit a simple linear regression ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} m <- lm(cumsum_good_aqi ~ date, data = tuc) m ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = cumsum_good_aqi ~ date, data = tuc) Coefficients: (Intercept) date -10644.57 0.62 ``` ::: ::: ## Detrend Step 2. Augment the data with model results (using `broom::augment()`) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc_aug <- augment(m) tuc_aug ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2,392 × 8 cumsum_good_aqi date .fitted .resid .hat .sigma 1 1 2017-01-01 -0.574 1.57 0.00167 23.9 2 2 2017-01-02 0.0457 1.95 0.00167 23.9 3 3 2017-01-03 0.666 2.33 0.00167 23.9 4 4 2017-01-04 1.29 2.71 0.00166 23.9 5 5 2017-01-05 1.91 3.09 0.00166 23.9 # ℹ 2,387 more rows # ℹ 2 more variables: .cooksd , .std.resid ``` ::: ::: ## Detrend Step 3. Divide the observed value of `cumsum_good_aqi` by the respective value in the long-term trend (i.e., `.fitted`) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc_aug <- tuc_aug |> mutate(ratio = cumsum_good_aqi / .fitted, .after = .fitted) tuc_aug ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2,392 × 9 cumsum_good_aqi date .fitted ratio .resid .hat .sigma 1 1 2017-01-01 -0.574 -1.74 1.57 0.00167 23.9 2 2 2017-01-02 0.0457 43.7 1.95 0.00167 23.9 3 3 2017-01-03 0.666 4.51 2.33 0.00167 23.9 4 4 2017-01-04 1.29 3.11 2.71 0.00166 23.9 5 5 2017-01-05 1.91 2.62 3.09 0.00166 23.9 # ℹ 2,387 more rows # ℹ 2 more variables: .cooksd , .std.resid ``` ::: ::: ## Visualize detrended data ::: panel-tabset ### Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-time-series-II_files/figure-revealjs/tuc-4-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ### Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tuc_aug |> ggplot(aes(x = date, y = ratio, group = 1)) + geom_hline(yintercept = 1, color = "gray") + geom_line() + scale_x_date( expand = expansion(mult = 0.1), date_labels = "%Y" ) + labs( x = NULL, y = "Number of days\n(detrended)", title = "Cumulative number of good AQI days (AQI < 50)", subtitle = "Tucson, AZ", caption = "\nSource: EPA Daily Air Quality Tracker" ) + theme(plot.title.position = "plot") ``` ::: ::: ## Air Quality in Tucson

::: hand barely anything interesting happening! ::: . . . ::: hand let's look at data from somewhere with a bit more "interesting" air quality data... ::: ## Read in multiple years of SF data {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} sf_files <- fs::dir_ls(here::here("data/san-francisco")) ``` ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} sf <- read_csv(sf_files, na = c(".", "")) sf <- sf |> janitor::clean_names() |> mutate( date = mdy(date), good_aqi = if_else(aqi_value <= 50, 1, 0) ) |> filter(!is.na(aqi_value)) |> arrange(date) |> mutate(cumsum_good_aqi = cumsum(good_aqi), .after = aqi_value) sf ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2,557 × 13 date aqi_value cumsum_good_aqi main_pollutant site_name 1 2016-01-01 32 1 PM2.5 Durham Arm… 2 2016-01-02 37 2 PM2.5 Durham Arm… 3 2016-01-03 45 3 PM2.5 Durham Arm… 4 2016-01-04 33 4 PM2.5 Durham Arm… 5 2016-01-05 27 5 PM2.5 Durham Arm… # ℹ 2,552 more rows # ℹ 8 more variables: site_id , source , # x20_year_high_2000_2019 , x20_year_low_2000_2019 , # x5_year_average_2015_2019 , date_of_20_year_high , # date_of_20_year_low , good_aqi ``` ::: ::: ## Plot trend since 2016 {.smaller} ::: panel-tabset ### Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-time-series-II_files/figure-revealjs/sf-1-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ### Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} sf |> ggplot(aes(x = date, y = cumsum_good_aqi, group = 1)) + geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "pink") + geom_line() + scale_x_date( expand = expansion(mult = 0.07), date_labels = "%Y" ) + labs( x = NULL, y = "Number of days", title = "Cumulative number of good AQI days (AQI < 50)", subtitle = "San Francisco-Oakland-Hayward, CA", caption = "\nSource: EPA Daily Air Quality Tracker" ) + theme(plot.title.position = "plot") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Detrend 1. Fit a simple linear regression ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} m_sf <- lm(cumsum_good_aqi ~ date, data = sf) ``` ::: . . . 2. Augment the data with model results ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} sf_aug <- augment(m_sf) ``` ::: . . . 3. Divide the observed value of `cumsum_good_aqi` by the respective value in the long-term trend (i.e., `.fitted`) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} sf_aug <- sf_aug |> mutate(ratio = cumsum_good_aqi / .fitted, .after = .fitted) ``` ::: ## Visualize detrended data ::: panel-tabset ### Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09-time-series-II_files/figure-revealjs/sf-2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ### Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} sf_aug |> ggplot(aes(x = date, y = ratio, group = 1)) + geom_hline(yintercept = 1, color = "gray") + geom_line() + scale_x_date( expand = expansion(mult = 0.07), date_labels = "%Y" ) + labs( x = NULL, y = "Number of days\n(detrended)", title = "Cumulative number of good AQI days (AQI < 50)", subtitle = "San Francisco-Oakland-Hayward, CA", caption = "\nSource: EPA Daily Air Quality Tracker" ) + theme(plot.title.position = "plot") ``` ::: ::: ## Detrending - In step 2 we fit a very simple model - Depending on the complexity you're trying to capture you might choose to fit a much more complex model - You can also decompose the trend into multiple trends, e.g. monthly, long-term, seasonal, etc.

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
